name: Milbemycin oxime + lufenuron
notes: Dosage ratio is 0.5 mg/kg Milbemycin to 10 mg/kg Lufenuron.

conditions.name: Intestinal Helminths
conditions.notes: Active against Toxocara canis, Ancylostoma caninum, Trichuris vulpis. T. leonina is also listed in other tables.

name: Milbemycin oxime + praziquantel
notes: Dosage ratio is 0.5 mg/kg Milbemycin to 5 mg/kg Praziquantel.

conditions.name: Intestinal Helminths
conditions.notes: Active against T. canis, Toxascaris leonina, A. caninum, T. vulpis, Dipylidium caninum, Taenia spp, Echinococcus spp.

name: Moxidectin + imidacloprid
notes: Dosage ratio is 2.5 mg/kg Moxidectin to 10 mg/kg Imidacloprid.

conditions.name: Intestinal Helminths
conditions.notes: Active against T. canis, T. leonina, A. caninum, Uncinaria stenocephala, T. vulpis.

conditions.name: Tapeworms
conditions.notes: Active against D. caninum, T. pisiformis.

name: Moxidectin (Injectable)
notes: Available as 6-month or 12-month product.

conditions.name: Intestinal Helminths (6-month)
conditions.notes: Active against A. caninum, U. stenocephala.

conditions.name: Intestinal Helminths (12-month)
conditions.notes: Active against A. caninum, U. stenocephala.

name: Piperazine (various salts)
notes: Max 150 mg/puppy.

conditions.name: Roundworms
conditions.notes: Repeat in 10 days and then monthly to prevent reinfection. Active against T. canis, T. leonina.

name: Praziquantel
notes: Available in oral and injectable forms. Max 170 mg/puppy or dog.

conditions.name: Tapeworms (Oral)
conditions.notes: Active against D. caninum, T. pisiformis, E. granulosus, E. multilocularis.

conditions.name: Tapeworms (Injectable)
conditions.notes: Can also be SubQ. Active against D. caninum, T. pisiformis, E. granulosus, E. multilocularis.

name: Pyrantel pamoate
notes: Dosage varies by weight.

conditions.name: Intestinal Helminths
conditions.notes: 10 mg/kg for dogs <= 2.3 kg. Monthly to prevent reinfection in adults. Active against T. canis, T. leonina, A. caninum, U. stenocephala.

name: Milbemycin oxime + afoxolaner
notes: Dosage ratio 0.5 mg/kg Milbemycin to 2.5 mg/kg Afoxolaner.

conditions.name: Intestinal Helminths
conditions.notes: Active against T. canis, T. leonina, A. caninum, A. braziliense, Ancylostoma ceylanicum, T. vulpis.

name: Fluoxetine (SSRI)
notes: Adverse effects: Anorexia, hyporexia, lethargy, sedation, vomiting, diarrhea, restlessness, vocalization, agitation, tremors, seizures, changes in urine frequency. Aggression has also been reported.

conditions.name: General Anxiety & Behavioral Disorders
conditions.notes: Extralabel indications include anxiety disorders, phobias, conflict aggression, fear aggression, compulsive disorders, excessive arousal, impulsivity, and urine marking.

name: Paroxetine (SSRI)
notes: Adverse effects: Lethargy, salivation, hyporexia, anorexia, vomiting, diarrhea, anxiety, irritability, aggression, insomnia, hyponatremia, mydriasis, hyperactivity or panting, constipation, urinary retention, cardiac arrhythmias. Less likely than fluoxetine to cause anorexia.

conditions.name: General Anxiety & Behavioral Disorders
conditions.notes: Extralabel. Indications: Anxiety disorders, phobias, conflict aggression, fear aggression, compulsive disorders, excessive arousal, impulsivity, and urine marking.

name: Sertraline (SSRI)
notes: Adverse effects: Anorexia, hyporexia, sedation, lethargy, vomiting, diarrhea, changes in urine frequency, excitement, anxiety, agitation, seizures.

conditions.name: General Anxiety & Behavioral Disorders
conditions.notes: Indications: Anxiety disorders, phobias, conflict aggression, fear aggression, compulsive disorders, excessive arousal, impulsivity, and urine marking.

name: Clomipramine (TCA)
notes: Adverse effects: Anorexia, hyporexia, vomiting, diarrhea, dry mouth, sedation, lethargy, depression, decreased total/free thyroxine, mydriasis, changes in liver enzymes, seizures.

conditions.name: Separation Anxiety (Label Dose)
conditions.notes: FDA approved. Can also be dosed 1-2 mg/kg q 12 h.

conditions.name: General Anxiety & Behavioral Disorders (Extralabel)
conditions.notes: Extralabel indications: Anxiety disorders, phobias, conflict aggression, fear aggression, compulsive disorders, excessive arousal, impulsivity, and urine marking.

name: Buspirone (azapirone)
notes: Adverse effects: Vomiting, diarrhea, nausea, agitation, behavioral disinhibition, bradycardia, stereotypical behaviors.

name: Trazodone (SARI)
notes: Adverse effects: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, sedation, ataxia, agitation, restlessness, increased anxiety, aggression, tachycardia. Hepatotoxicosis and priapism reported.

conditions.name: Anxiety Disorders
conditions.notes: Up to 19.5 mg/kg in any 24-h period. Indications: Anxiety, fear aggression, compulsive disorders, sedation/anxiolysis for veterinary care, postsurgical confinement.

name: Clonidine (alpha-2-adrenergic agonist)
notes: Adverse effects: Sedation, hypotension, nausea, dry mouth, ataxia, sleep disturbances, excitement, urinary incontinence, bradycardia, collapse.

conditions.name: Anxiety and Phobias
conditions.notes: Extralabel. Can be given q 8-12 h when administered regularly. Indications: Anxiety, fear, phobias, panic, neuropathic pain.

name: Dexmedetomidine oral gel
notes: Adverse effects: Sedation, vomiting, gastroenteritis, drowsiness, inappropriate urination. DO NOT SWALLOW - Transmucosal absorption.

conditions.name: Noise Aversion
conditions.notes: IMPORTANT: Dosage is 125 mcg per square meter (m2), NOT mg/kg. Apply oral transmucosal. FDA approved for noise aversion. Extralabel for other fear/anxiety.

name: Gabapentin
notes: Adverse effects: Sedation, ataxia, vomiting, diarrhea, increased appetite, agitation, excitement.

conditions.name: Regular Administration
conditions.notes: Indications: Anxiety, fear, neuropathic pain, seizures.

conditions.name: Situational (Event-based)
conditions.notes: Give 90 minutes before stressor as needed.

name: Alprazolam (benzodiazepine)
notes: Adverse effects: Sedation, increased appetite, ataxia, muscle relaxation, anxiety, paradoxical excitation, aggression.

conditions.name: Anxiety and Phobias
conditions.notes: Extralabel. Indications: Anxiety, fear, phobias, seizures.

name: Loperamide
notes: In patients with ABCB1-delta mutation, loperamide may penetrate the blood-brain barrier and produce CNS effects (profound sedation).

name: Aspirin
notes: Not required, but hematocrit and renal function should be periodically monitored. Generally less efficacious than clopidogrel.

name: Clopidogrel
notes: Not required, but platelet aggregometry is useful in research settings.

name: Rivaroxaban
notes: Not required, but specific anti-Xa activity is useful in research settings.

name: Dalteparin
notes: Not required, but titration to target anti-Xa activity has been investigated.

name: Enoxaparin
notes: Not required, but can consider titration to target anti-Xa activity.

name: Unfractionated heparin
notes: Close monitoring of activated clotting time, aPTT, or anti-Xa activity is necessary due to narrow therapeutic index. Monitor for hyperkalemia.

name: Tissue plasminogen activator (Alteplase)
notes: Hospitalized patients with intensive monitoring and 24-h observation only. Total volume must not exceed 0.1 mL.

conditions.name: Ulcers (Loading/CRI)
conditions.notes: Loading dose 1 mg/kg IV followed by 8 mg/kg/d CRI

name: Amphotericin B
notes: Nephrotoxic; monitor kidneys. Protect from light. Administer slowly over 2-6 hours.

conditions.name: Systemic mycoses
conditions.notes: Cats are more sensitive; lower doses recommended.

name: Flucytosine
notes: Used in combination with Amphotericin B. Resistance develops frequently.

name: Potassium Iodide
notes: Do not use in pregnant or lactating animals.

conditions.name: Sporotrichosis (Maintenance)
conditions.notes: Follows initial IV Sodium Iodide treatment

name: Sodium Iodide
notes: Do not use in pregnant or lactating animals.

name: Ceftiofur sodium
notes: Cephalosporins are prohibited from extralabel drug use (ELDU) in major food-producing animal species in the US. Do not inject more than 15 mL per injection site in cattle.

name: Ceftiofur crystalline-free acid
notes: Cephalosporins are prohibited from extralabel drug use (ELDU) in major food-producing animal species in the US. Cattle: Administer in base of the ear. Swine: Max 2 mL per injection site.

conditions.name: Acute metritis (Lactating dairy)
conditions.notes: Repeat dose in opposite ear in 72 h

conditions.name: Fungal infection
conditions.frequency: q 24 h (5 days on/2 days off)

name: Erythromycin
notes: No approved veterinary erythromycin products are available in the US for beef cattle.

conditions.name: Bacterial infection (Foals)
conditions.notes: Do not use in adult horses. Use erythromycin base or estolate products.

name: Tilmicosin
notes: Accidental self-injection can be fatal to humans.

conditions.name: Bacterial infection (Foals)
conditions.notes: Off-label; Do not use in adult horses. Usually in combination with rifampin.

conditions.name: Bacterial infection (Foals - Alternative)
conditions.notes: Off-label; Do not use in adult horses.

name: Sodium penicillin G
notes: ELDU in cattle. Meat withdrawal time for turkeys is 1 day.

conditions.name: Refractory cases
conditions.notes: Doses up to 44,000 U/kg have been used

name: Potassium penicillin G
notes: Contains considerable potassium; use caution in horses with HYPP and sensitive patients.

conditions.name: Bacterial infection
conditions.notes: Doses up to 44,000 U/kg have been used in refractory cases

name: Procaine penicillin G
notes: Doses > 6,600 U/kg/d constitute ELDU in cattle and swine.

name: Benzathine penicillin G
notes: ELDU in camelids. Greatly extended withdrawal times for production animals. Doses > 8,800 U/kg constitute ELDU in cattle.

name: Cloxacillin sodium
notes: Meat withdrawal: 10 days; Milk withdrawal: 48 hours.

name: Cloxacillin benzathine
notes: Meat withdrawal: 28 days.

name: Ampicillin sodium
notes: ELDU in cattle, small ruminants, camelids, and swine.

name: Ampicillin trihydrate
notes: Injection is a suspension; should NOT be administered IV due to risk of anaphylaxis and death.

name: Amoxicillin
notes: ELDU in poultry; requires VFD.

name: Amoxicillin-clavulanate
notes: ELDU in poultry.

name: Ertapenem
notes: Reserved class, not for empiric treatment.

name: Imipenem cilastatin sodium
notes: Reserved class, not for empiric treatment. May lower seizure threshold in dogs/cats.

name: Meropenem
notes: Reserved class, not for empiric treatment.

name: Ticarcillin-clavulanate
notes: Reserved class, not for empiric treatment.

name: Trimethoprim-sulfadiazine
notes: Approved veterinary products are available with a trimethoprim-to-sulfadiazine ratio of 1:4; dosages are based on the total mg of the combination.

name: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
notes: Extra-label drug use (ELDU).

name: Ciprofloxacin
notes: ELDU. Not well absorbed in cats; highly variable absorption in dogs. Do not use in horses; can result in fatal colitis.

name: Danofloxacin
notes: ELDU prohibited. Injection site volume not to exceed 15 mL/site.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Multi Dose)
conditions.notes: Excluding veal and dairy cattle. Give for 2 doses.

name: Enrofloxacin
notes: Extralabel use of fluorinated quinolones in food-producing animals is prohibited in the US.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection
conditions.notes: Can also be administered IV or SC.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection
conditions.notes: Can also be administered IV or SC. Use with caution; retinal degeneration and blindness can result.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Single Dose)
conditions.notes: Excluding veal and lactating dairy. ELDU prohibited. Injection site volume not to exceed 20 mL/site.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Multi Dose)
conditions.notes: Excluding veal and lactating dairy. ELDU prohibited.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (IV)
conditions.notes: ELDU. Use with caution in young foals because of cartilage damage risk.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Oral)
conditions.notes: ELDU. Use with caution in young foals because of cartilage damage risk.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection
conditions.notes: Or SC (postauricular). ELDU prohibited. All use classes.

name: Orbifloxacin
notes: Suspension is variably absorbed compared with tablets. Use with caution in cats; retinal degeneration and blindness can result.

name: Pradofloxacin
notes: Extralabel use of fluorinated quinolones in food-producing animals is prohibited in the US.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection
conditions.notes: ELDU. Higher doses associated with myelosuppression. Do not use in dogs <12 months old.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection
conditions.notes: Beef cattle intended for slaughter and replacement beef/dairy heifers/bulls < 1 year old. ELDU prohibited. Injection site volume not to exceed 15 mL/site.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection
conditions.notes: Weaned swine intended for slaughter. ELDU prohibited. Injection site volume not to exceed 5 mL/site.

name: Sulfamethazine
notes: ELDU of sulfonamides is prohibited in lactating dairy cattle in the US.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Maintenance)
conditions.notes: Follows loading dose. Cattle and horses.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Calves - Loading)
conditions.notes: Initial dose. Calves. Administer as drench or drinking water.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Calves - Maintenance)
conditions.notes: Follows loading dose. Calves. Administer as drench or drinking water.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Loading Dose)
conditions.notes: Initial dose. Administer as drench or drinking water.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Maintenance)
conditions.notes: Follows loading dose. Administer as drench or drinking water.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection
conditions.notes: Chickens, excluding layers. Administer as medicated water.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Loading Dose)
conditions.notes: Initial dose. Excluding veal. Route can be PO or IV.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Maintenance)
conditions.notes: Follows loading dose. Excluding veal. Route can be PO or IV.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Loading Dose)
conditions.notes: Initial dose. Route can be PO, IV, or SC.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Maintenance)
conditions.notes: Follows loading dose. Route can be PO, IV, or SC.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Loading Dose)
conditions.notes: Initial dose. Route can be PO, IV, or SC.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Maintenance)
conditions.notes: Follows loading dose. Route can be PO, IV, or SC.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection
conditions.notes: Chickens (excluding layers). Drinking water solution. Also available as a veterinary feed directive product.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection
conditions.notes: Route can be PO or IV.

name: Tetracycline
notes: ELDU; there are no injectable tetracycline products available in the US.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Injectable)
conditions.notes: Or IM. ELDU; no injectable products available in US.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Injectable)
conditions.notes: Or IM. ELDU; no injectable products available in US.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Multi Dose)
conditions.notes: Excluding veal. Route can be SC, IM, or IV.

conditions.name: Susceptible Infection (Single Dose)
conditions.notes: Excluding veal. Route can be SC or IM.

name: Doxycycline
notes: ELDU; administration of solid dosage forms to cats should be followed by food or at least 6 mL of liquid to prevent esophageal erosions.

conditions.name: Appetite Stimulation (> 30 kg)
conditions.notes: For dogs > 30 kg. No more than 30 mg per dog.

name: Apomorphine
notes: Used to induce vomiting.

name: Xylazine
notes: Used to induce vomiting in cats.

name: Dexmedetomidine
notes: Used to induce vomiting in cats.

name: Hydrogen peroxide
notes: Cats: NOT RECOMMENDED.

name: Ivermectin
notes: Dose depends on product and species. Some recommendations constitute off-label use.

conditions.name: Lungworm (Dictyocaulus viviparus) - Oral/SubQ
conditions.notes: Route can be PO or SC.

conditions.name: Lungworm (Oslerus osleri)
conditions.notes: May need up to three doses. Anecdotal evidence.

name: Moxidectin
notes: Some recommendations constitute off-label use.

conditions.name: Lungworm (D. arnfieldi)
conditions.notes: Anecdotal evidence for efficacy. Also for Donkeys.

name: Doxylamine succinate
notes: Ethanolamine-derivative antihistamine.

name: Meclizine
notes: Piperazine-derivative antihistamine.

name: Promethazine
notes: Phenothiazine-derivative antihistamine.

name: Loratadine
notes: Tricyclic, long-acting histamine. Often found in combination with pseudoephedrine, which can result in more serious clinical signs.

name: Chlorpheniramine
notes: Propylamine-derivative antihistamine. Mild clinical signs (depression, GI upset) can occur at < 1 mg/kg.

name: Clemastine
notes: Ethanolamine-derivative antihistamine. 1.35 mg clemastine fumarate is equivalent to 1 mg clemastine.

name: Diphenhydramine
notes: Ethanolamine-derivative antihistamine.

name: Hydroxyzine
notes: Piperazine-derivative antihistamine. Mild clinical signs can occur at therapeutic doses.

name: Cetirizine
notes: Piperazine-derivative antihistamine. Well tolerated by dogs and cats.

name: Fexofenadine
notes: Butyrophenone-derivative antihistamine. Often found in combination with pseudoephedrine, which can result in more serious clinical signs.

name: Diazepam
notes: Adverse effects: Sedation, increased appetite, ataxia, muscle relaxation, anxiety, paradoxical excitation, aggression. Used to induce vomiting in cats.

conditions.name: Anxiety and Phobias
conditions.notes: Extralabel. Indications: Anxiety, fear, phobias, seizures, appetite stimulant, muscle relaxant.

name: Fluconazole
notes: Can be administered with or without food.

name: Itraconazole
notes: Administer with food. Do not use with antacids. Vasculitis possible at doses >10 mg/kg.

name: Ketoconazole
notes: Requires acidic environment (no antacids). Hepatotoxicity possible. Cats are more sensitive.

name: Terbinafine
notes: Allylamine antifungal.

name: Fenbendazole
notes: Two dosage regimens available depending on indication.

conditions.name: Intestinal Helminths (3-Day Course)
conditions.notes: Active against T. canis, T. leonina, A. caninum, U. stenocephala, T. vulpis, Taenia pisiformis.

conditions.name: Intestinal Helminths (Single Dose)
conditions.notes: Active against T. canis, T. leonina, Ancylostoma spp, Uncinaria spp, Trichuris spp, Taenia spp, Oslerus osleri (requires 7 days).

name: Milbemycin oxime
notes: Standalone product.

conditions.name: Intestinal Helminths
conditions.notes: Active against T. canis, T. leonina, A. caninum, T. vulpis.

name: Marquis Paste
notes: Shake bottle well, separates.

conditions.name: Coccidia
conditions.notes: Can be done longer when needed.

conditions.name: Coccidia
conditions.notes: Can be done longer when needed.

name: Reglan (Metoclopramide)
notes: DVM Rx Only. Used for parvo, or cats/dogs not eating/vomiting.

name: Cerenia
notes: Very expensive!

conditions.name: Motion Sickness
conditions.notes: Fast 1 hour before. Give 2 hours before travel. Max 2 days in a row.

name: Ondansetron
notes: Used later in treatment for not eating/vomiting.

name: Gentamicin Drops
notes: Corneal ulcers (stain first), yellow/green discharge.

conditions.name: Conjunctivitis / Ulcers
conditions.notes: Recipe: 15ml mineral oil or artificial tears + Gentamycin 100mg/ml 0.5ml

conditions.name: Conjunctivitis / Ulcers
conditions.notes: Recipe: 15ml mineral oil or artificial tears + Gentamycin 100mg/ml 0.5ml

name: Ciprofloxacin Drops
notes: DVM Rx Only. Infection, inflammation, ulcers (stain first).

name: BNP Ointment
notes: DVM Rx Only. Normally for dogs. Can cause rare reaction in cats.

name: Tramadol
notes: DVM Rx Only. Controlled substance. Post surgery pain.

conditions.name: Pain
conditions.notes: 0-9 lbs: 1/4 tab; 10-20lbs: 1/2 tab; 21-40 lbs: 1 tab; 40-55 lbs: 1.5 tab; 55-75lbs: 2 tab.

name: Tramadol / Tinic
notes: DVM Rx Only! Crush 2 tablets for every 10cc (10mg/ml). Feline post surgery pain.

name: Buprenorphine SR (3mg/mL)
notes: DVM Rx Only! SQ only, lasts 3 days. Better than Tram/Tinic but expensive.

name: Rimadyl / Deramaxx
notes: DVM Rx Only! Do not use with other NSAIDs or steroids!

name: Metacam (Meloxicam)
notes: DVM Rx Only! Do not use with other NSAIDs or steroids! Can be used for high fevers in cats.

name: Metronidazole (Flagyl)
notes: Used for Giardia and IBD. Bitter taste.

conditions.name: BANNED
conditions.notes: BANNED IN FOOD ANIMALS. Do not administer.

name: Tylenol (Acetaminophen)
notes: FATAL TO CATS. Use with caution in dogs; liver toxicity risk.

conditions.name: Pain / Fever
conditions.notes: Based on PDF: 1 Regular Strength (325mg) per 55 lbs. Do NOT give to cats.

conditions.name: Motion Sickness
conditions.notes: Approx 1 tablet (50mg) per 25 lbs (PDF says 1 per 14-28 lbs).

name: Robenacoxib (Onsior)
notes: Cats < 12 lbs.

name: Tresaderm
notes: Keep refrigerated.

name: Pimobendan (Vetmedin)
notes: Contraindicated in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM).

conditions.name: Congestive Heart Failure
conditions.notes: Typical dose per cat is 1.25 mg.

name: Oclacitinib (Apoquel)
notes: Do not use in dogs < 12 months or with serious infections.

conditions.name: Atopic Dermatitis
conditions.notes: BID for up to 14 days, then SID maintenance.

name: Sildenafil (Viagra)
notes: Improves energy/quality of life in heart/lung patients.

name: Enalapril
notes: ACE Inhibitor. Do not use in pregnant pets. FDA approved for dogs, commonly used in cats.

name: Levothyroxine (Thyro-Tabs)
notes: Monitor T4 levels. Overdose causes panting/thirst.

conditions.name: Hypothyroidism
conditions.notes: Dose is PER CAT, not per lb.

name: Florphenicol
notes: Not for use in dairy cattle. Do not exceed 10ml per injection site.

name: Florphenicol + Flunixin (Resflor Gold)
notes: Rx. High dose/long acting. Rapid IV can cause collapse.

conditions.name: Pneumonia / Pinkeye / Foot Rot
conditions.notes: 9 mg/lb. Max 10ml per site. Meat Withdrawal: 28 days. Milk Discard: 96 hours.

name: Chlortetracycline (Feed Grade)
notes: VFD Required. Illegal for growth promotion.

conditions.name: Anaplasmosis / Pneumonia Control
conditions.notes: Withdrawal varies by formulation (often 0 days for anaplasmosis control). Check VFD label.

conditions.name: Clinical Mastitis
conditions.notes: Repeat once in 24 hours. Meat Withdrawal: 2 days. Milk Discard: 72 hours.

name: Amprolium (Corid)
notes: Thiamine deficiency risk with prolonged use.

conditions.name: Coccidiosis (Prevention)
conditions.notes: 8 oz of 9.6% solution per 100 gal water. Meat Withdrawal: 24 hours.

conditions.name: Coccidiosis (Treatment)
conditions.notes: 16 oz of 9.6% solution per 100 gal water. Meat Withdrawal: 24 hours.

name: Flunixin Meglumine (Banamine)
notes: Rx. Injectable is IV ONLY (IM causes necrosis).

conditions.name: Fever / Endotoxemia (Injectable)
conditions.notes: Meat Withdrawal: 4 days. Milk Discard: 36 hours. Do not inject IM.

conditions.name: Fever (Transdermal Pour-On)
conditions.notes: Meat Withdrawal: 8 days. Milk Discard: 48 hours.

conditions.name: Colic / Pain
conditions.notes: Can be given BID for short periods.

name: Dexamethasone
notes: Rx. INDUCES ABORTION in pregnant cattle/animals. Immunosuppressive.

name: Prostaglandins (Lutalyse/Estrumate)
notes: Rx. CAUTION: Absorbed through skin. Risk to women/asthmatics.

name: Thiamine (500 mg/mL)
notes: Use high concentration (500mg/ml) for Polioencephalomalacia.
